text: Réka Vidáts (born 19 July 1979) is a Hungarian former professional tennis player. ==Biography== As a junior, Vidáts was an Australian Open quarter- finalist and had a win over Martina Hingis, at the Italian Junior Championships in 1994. Vidáts reached a top ranking of 193 on the professional tour. She twice received a wildcard to compete in the main draw of the Hungarian Ladies Open and featured as a qualifier at the 1995 Indonesia Open. In 1997 she played in Wimbledon qualifiers and appeared in three Fed Cup ties for Hungary. Based in Marbella, Vidáts now runs an events company. ==ITF finals== ===Singles (1–1)=== {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%" !Legend |- style="background:lightblue;" |$25,000 tournaments |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" |$10,000 tournaments |} {|class="sortable wikitable" style=font-size:97% !Outcome !No. !Date !Tournament !Surface !Opponent !Score |- bgcolor="#f0f8ff" | bgcolor="98FB98"|Winner | 1. | 8 August 1994 | Rebecq, Belgium | Clay | Stephanie Devillé | 6–2, 3–6, 6–3 |-bgcolor="#f0f8ff" | bgcolor="FFA07A"|Runner-up | 2. | 29 August 1994 | London, United Kingdom | Grass | Denisa Sobotková | 6–7, 4–6 |} ===Doubles (2–4)=== {|class="sortable wikitable" style=font-size:97% !Outcome !No. !Date !Tournament !Surface !Partner !Opponents !Score |- style="background:#f0f8ff;" | bgcolor="FFA07A"|Runner-up | 1. | 12 September 1994 | Cluj-Napoca, Romania | Clay | Kati Kocsis | Petra Filipová Olga Vymetálková | 6–4, 2–6, 4–6 |- bgcolor="lightblue" | bgcolor="FFA07A"|Runner-up | 2. | 23 September 1995 | Sofia, Bulgaria | Clay | Lubomira Bacheva | Geraldine Aizenberg Laura Montalvo | 2–6, 2–6 |- bgcolor="lightblue" | bgcolor="98FB98"|Winner | 3. | 19 August 1996 | Kiev, Ukraine | Clay | Anna-Karin Svensson | Natalia Medvedeva Anna Zaporozhanova | 7–5, 6–3 |- bgcolor="lightblue" | bgcolor="FFA07A"|Runner-up | 4. | 27 July 1997 | Rostock, Germany | Clay | Renee Reid | Svetlana Krivencheva Pavlina Nola | w/o |- bgcolor="lightblue" | bgcolor="FFA07A"|Runner-up | 5. | 10 November 1997 | Mount Gambier, Australia | Hard | Renee Reid | Catherine Barclay Kim Eun-ha | 3–6, 2–6 |- bgcolor="#f0f8ff" | bgcolor="98FB98"|Winner | 6. | 22 June 1998 | Kavala, Greece | Hard | Maria Pavlidou | Branka Bojović Evagelia Roussi | 6–1, 6–1 |} ==See also== *List of Hungary Fed Cup team representatives ==References== ==External links== * * * Category:1979 births Category:Living people Category:Hungarian female tennis players Category:Hungarian expatriates in Spain
